issue.title: [joy-ui][material-ui][Tabs] Change aria-selected to aria-current

labels.name: accessibility
labels.description: a11y

labels.name: component: tabs
labels.description: This is the name of the generic UI component, not the React module!

labels.name: package: material-ui
labels.description: Specific to @mui/material

labels.name: package: joy-ui
labels.description: Specific to @mui/joy

issue.body:
Closes #32924 

<!-- Thanks so much for your PR, your contribution is appreciated! ❤️ -->

- [x] I have followed (at least) the [PR section of the contributing guide](https://github.com/mui/material-ui/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#sending-a-pull-request).

This PR changed `aria-selected` to `aria-current` in `Tab` component. 

From the MDN docs:

> When you have a group of related elements, such as several links in a breadcrumb or steps in a multi-step flow, with one element in the group styled differently from the others to indicate to the sighted user that this is the current element within its group, the aria-current should be used to inform the assistive technology user what has been indicated via styling.


the aria-selected docs define the following.

> The [option](https://w3c.github.io/aria/#option), [tab](https://w3c.github.io/aria/#tab), and [treeitem](https://w3c.github.io/aria/#treeitem) roles permit user agents to provide an implicit value for [aria-selected](https://w3c.github.io/aria/#aria-selected) when specified conditions are met

comment.body:
> Why would we need both? Neither ARIA docs nor demos for the tab role mention the `aria-current` attribute. Is there an accessibility issue you're trying to fix?

there was an open issue for that and I have trying to fix #32924 
am I getting the issue wrong?

issue.title: [Snackbar][Material You] convert .js files to .ts
issue.body:
<!-- Thanks so much for your PR, your contribution is appreciated! ❤️ -->

- [x] I have followed (at least) the [PR section of the contributing guide](https://github.com/mui/material-ui/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#sending-a-pull-request).

related to: https://github.com/mui/material-ui/issues/39207

In this PR, I have converted the Snackbar files from JavaScript to TypeScript.
Furthermore, to apply the Material Design 3 specs, I also need to migrate the SnackbarContent component to mui-material-next. I will submit the changes for SnackbarContent in a separate PR.

issue.title: Bump next from 11.1.4 to 13.5.0 in /test/bundling/fixtures/next-webpack4

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Update of dependencies.

issue.body:
Bumps [next](https://github.com/vercel/next.js) from 11.1.4 to 13.5.0.
Release notes

Sourced from next's releases.

v13.4.20-canary.41

Core Changes

  • Add mui-core to the default optimizePackageImports list: #55554
  • Consolidate experimental React opt-in & add ppr flag: #55560
  • Add react-icons to optimizePackageImports: #55572
  • Fix useState function initialiser case for optimize_server_react transform: #55551
  • Update supported config options for Turbopack: #55556
  • Fix react packages are not bundled for metadata routes: #55579
  • improve internal error logging: #55582
  • fix styled-jsx alias: #55581

Documentation Changes

  • chore: Fix heading hierarchy in revalidateTag documentation: #55470
  • chore: replace issue triaing actions with nissuer: #55525

Credits

Huge thanks to @​romeobravo, @​shuding, @​ztanner, @​balazsorban44, @​padmaia, @​huozhi, and @​sokra for helping!

v13.4.20-canary.40

Core Changes

  • Fix missing module.compiled trace file and unhandledRejection in ensurePage: #55553

Example Changes

  • Type Error on Event Type payment_intent webhook: #55493
  • Correct spelling in playwright docs: #55557

Credits

Huge thanks to @​roigecode, @​hoop71, and @​ijjk for helping!

v13.4.20-canary.39

Core Changes

  • fix next.js own build on windows: #55544
  • Fix notFound status code with ISR in app: #55542
  • Disable client-only for middleware and pages api layer: #55541

Documentation Changes

  • Add route groups example to revalidatePath doc: #55543

Misc Changes

  • chore(third-parties): replace rimraf with rm.mjs: #55547

... (truncated)

Commits
  • ffafad2 v13.5.0
  • 4a589ed v13.4.20-canary.41
  • deb81cf fix styled-jsx alias (#55581)
  • 1a9b0f6 improve internal error logging (#55582)
  • 0631549 Fix react packages are not bundled for metadata routes (#55579)
  • bad5365 Update supported config options for Turbopack (#55556)
  • 8881c41 Fix useState function initialiser case for optimize_server_react transform ...
  • 1025011 Add react-icons to optimizePackageImports (#55572)
  • d5c35a1 chore: replace issue triaing actions with nissuer (#55525)
  • 33c561b Consolidate experimental React opt-in & add ppr flag (#55560)
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

comment.body: @mui/code-infra we have these bundling fixtures for webpack v4 and webpack v5. Considering v5 was released three years ago, should we still keep them? In my opinion if we have bundling tests it should be more about testing latest webpack with the few of the last next versions.

issue.title: TextField type="number", treats 1e as an empty value instead of treating it as a wrong input/error

labels.name: docs
labels.description: Improvements or additions to the documentation

labels.name: component: text field
labels.description: This is the name of the generic UI component, not the React module!

issue.body:
### Duplicates - [X] I have searched the existing issues ### Latest version - [X] I have tested the latest version ### Steps to reproduce 🕹 Link to live example: Steps: 1. 2. 3. ### Current behavior 😯 1) Create a TextField with type="number" 2) It allows inputs of the form 1e2, 2e3, etc... which is correct 3) If I stop at 1e, it assumes the value to be empty, and when I move away from the field, if there is a helperText that the developer has set for empty value, it gives that message. This is wrong. ### Expected behavior 🤔 It should validate and say that it is not a proper number when the user stops at 1e. ### Context 🔦 _No response_ ### Your environment 🌎
npx @mui/envinfo ``` Don't forget to mention which browser you used. Output from `npx @mui/envinfo` goes here. ```

comment.body:
Thanks. What else can we use then for number inputs? I see that NumberInput component is still in the beta version of Mui/BaseUI and even that doesn’t allow ‘e’ as input?
Similar validation problem we are facing with input type=”datetime-local” if the user enters 30/02, it becomes tough to validate as it treats it as an empty string. I am assuming we should be using MUIx/DatePickers for that? Thanks.

From: Albert Yu ***@***.***>
Sent: Friday, October 27, 2023 2:52 PM
To: mui/material-ui ***@***.***>
Cc: Shivacharan Saluvendri ***@***.***>; Mention ***@***.***>
Subject: Re: [mui/material-ui] TextField type="number", treats 1e as an empty value instead of treating it as a wrong input/error (Issue #39627)


@shivasaluvendri<https://github.com/shivasaluvendri> We don't recommend using type="number" on a TextField, the issue you raised is just one of many issues with the native number input 😅

See #39629<https://github.com/mui/material-ui/pull/39629> for details

—

issue.title: [TextField] autoFocus doesn't seem to be working

labels.name: external dependency
labels.description: We can’t do anything about it. (It’s not our responsibility)

labels.name: component: text field
labels.description: This is the name of the generic UI component, not the React module!

issue.body:
### Problem description

I tried making auto focus on my TextField with no success.

I also looked and saw that the `autoFocus` is being `@ignore` from the docs. Why is that?

Tried with `autoFocus={true}`
```js
<TextField
        autoFocus={true}
        onChange={ (e) => debounceOnChange(e.target.value) }
        type="search"
      />
```

Tried with `inputProps={true}`

```js
<TextField
        inputProps={autofocus: {true}}
        onChange={ (e) => debounceOnChange(e.target.value) }
        type="search"
      />
```

And even `InputProps`:
```js
<TextField
        InputProps={autofocus: {true}}
        onChange={ (e) => debounceOnChange(e.target.value) }
        type="search"
      />
```

### Versions

- Material-UI: 1.0.0-alpha-19
- React: 15.6.1
- Browser: Al of them

issue.body:
### Duplicates - [X] I have searched the existing issues ### Latest version - [X] I have tested the latest version ### Steps to reproduce 🕹 Trying to use Joy UI's Autocomplete in a controlled state as per the docs, I get a TypeScript error: ![image](https://github.com/mui/material-ui/assets/9912830/28d833a3-3694-4ed7-8ea2-60ab907ed8f1) I also get a runtime error on the browser from React. ![image](https://github.com/mui/material-ui/assets/9912830/43f0ff6f-2cb7-4dd4-88d6-576ccd72b44b) I've tried passing objects with `value` and `label` as options, passing a `value` prop, but I also get the same typescript error. It expects it to be an array of `string` or the inferred type from option. I also get errors if I pass it an array. Am I using this component wrong, or is there an issue with these types? Reproduction: (MUI Joy's own example has type errors) https://codesandbox.io/s/cp2zmj?file=/Demo.tsx ### Current behavior 😯 _No response_ ### Expected behavior 🤔 _No response_ ### Context 🔦 _No response_ ### Your environment 🌎
npx @mui/envinfo ``` Don't forget to mention which browser you used. Output from `npx @mui/envinfo` goes here. ```

comment.body: This is already being tracked in #23708.

issue.title: [Select][base-ui] Keyboard navigation does not work in Safari

labels.name: component: select
labels.description: This is the name of the generic UI component, not the React module!

labels.name: package: base-ui
labels.description: Specific to @mui/base

issue.body:
### Duplicates

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Latest version

- [X] I have tested the latest version

### Steps to reproduce 🕹

Link to live example: https://mui.com/joy-ui/react-select/#basic-usage

Steps:

1. Open the example in Safari
2. Use the arrow keys to select an option (this does not work)
**or** use the tab key to focus the Select (this does not work)


### Current behavior 😯

The Joy Select component does not work with the keyboard in **Safari**. There are two issues:

- Selecting an option with the arrow keys does not work. Instead, the arrow keys scroll the page.
- Unlike the MUI Select, the Joy Select cannot be selected with the tab key. This is an accessibility issues, especially when filling out forms.

### Expected behavior 🤔

The Joy Select should work with the keyboard in Safari as it does in Chrome. The arrow keys should select menu items, and the tab key should focus the Select.

### Context 🔦

_No response_

### Your environment 🌎

_No response_

issue.title: [useInput][base-ui] Fix inputRef in useInput's return value

labels.name: package: base-ui
labels.description: Specific to @mui/base

labels.name: component: input
labels.description: This is the name of the generic UI component, not the React module!

comment.body:
> What do you think about this alternative?: https://codesandbox.io/s/39599-alternative-j659ss.

This is exactly how it's intended to be used. We can't return `inputRef` (an object) because if someone assigns something else to its `.current`, it will be not in sync with other refs. When keeping refs in sync using `useForkRef`, we have to use the returned function.

issue.title: [material-ui][InputBase] Auto-fill keyframes may cause unwanted animations

labels.name: package: material-ui
labels.description: Specific to @mui/material

labels.name: status: needs triage
labels.description: These issues haven't been looked at yet by a maintainer.

labels.name: component: input
labels.description: This is the name of the generic UI component, not the React module!

labels.name: Port to v6.x
labels.description: Fixes made in v5 that need to be ported to v6 before its release

issue.body:
### Duplicates - [X] I have searched the existing issues ### Latest version - [X] I have tested the latest version ### Steps to reproduce 🕹 Link to live example: https://stackblitz.com/edit/react-tsmx9v?file=src%2Fstyle.css Steps: 1. Load the page in Chrome 117 or newer ### Current behavior 😯 The very first frame has the text input box rendered extra tall. The next frame has it at the normal size. This is happening because the mui-auto-fill-cancel keyframes rule starts an animation. ### Expected behavior 🤔 No animation should be started and the first frame should be the same as the final state. ### Context 🔦 Hello! I recently implemented a feature in chrome which makes the `display` property animatable: https://chromestatus.com/feature/5154958272364544 Before I made this change, `@keyframes` rules with `display` in them did nothing. The mui-auto-fill keyframes rules in particular would have not started an animation because they didn't contain any animatable properties. Now that `display` is animatable, it is creating an animation which is only lasting for a single frame. This was added here: https://github.com/mui/material-ui/pull/28070 Based on the issue which that PR fixed, it sounds like there has to be some styles inside the keyframes which don't actually start an animation. I recommend using a property which is pretty much guaranteed to never be upgraded to become animatable, such as the `animation-name` property. So perhaps replacing `display:block` with `animation-name:hello-world` would fix it? ### Your environment 🌎
npx @mui/envinfo ``` Don't forget to mention which browser you used. Output from `npx @mui/envinfo` goes here. ```

issue.title: [Autocomplete] Unable to access the Input element's ref or give it a ref

labels.name: component: autocomplete
labels.description: This is the name of the generic UI component, not the React module!

issue.body:
### Duplicates - [X] I have searched the existing issues ### Latest version - [X] I have tested the latest version ### Steps to reproduce 🕹 Link to live example: https://codesandbox.io/s/amazing-volhard-knjtci?file=/index.tsx Steps: Click Input element ### Current behavior 😯 MUI occur error when click Input element. ### Expected behavior 🤔 Will not raise error and assign ref to its inner input element. ### Context 🔦 I want to handle inner input element with its ref. But, when I create ref with `useRef` and transfer to input element, MUI always occur error. There is a way with using `getInputProps().ref` to get input element's ref, but it has an error too.(https://github.com/mui/material-ui/issues/36552) ### Your environment 🌎
npx @mui/envinfo ``` System: OS: macOS 12.5.1 Binaries: Node: 16.1.0 - ~/.volta/tools/image/node/16.1.0/bin/node Yarn: 4.0.0-rc.39 - ~/.volta/tools/image/yarn/4.0.0-rc.39/bin/yarn npm: 7.11.2 - ~/.volta/tools/image/node/16.1.0/bin/npm Browsers: Chrome: 111.0.5563.64 Edge: Not Found Firefox: Not Found Safari: 15.6.1 ```

issue.title: TextField type="number", treats 1e as an empty value instead of treating it as a wrong input/error

labels.name: docs
labels.description: Improvements or additions to the documentation

labels.name: component: text field
labels.description: This is the name of the generic UI component, not the React module!

issue.body:
### Duplicates - [X] I have searched the existing issues ### Latest version - [X] I have tested the latest version ### Steps to reproduce 🕹 Link to live example: Steps: 1. 2. 3. ### Current behavior 😯 1) Create a TextField with type="number" 2) It allows inputs of the form 1e2, 2e3, etc... which is correct 3) If I stop at 1e, it assumes the value to be empty, and when I move away from the field, if there is a helperText that the developer has set for empty value, it gives that message. This is wrong. ### Expected behavior 🤔 It should validate and say that it is not a proper number when the user stops at 1e. ### Context 🔦 _No response_ ### Your environment 🌎
npx @mui/envinfo ``` Don't forget to mention which browser you used. Output from `npx @mui/envinfo` goes here. ```

comment.body:
@shivasaluvendri We don't recommend using `type="number"` on a `TextField`, the issue you raised is just one of many issues with the native number `input` 😅 

See https://github.com/mui/material-ui/pull/39629 for details

issue.title: [docs] Remove numeric input workaround from TextField docs

labels.name: docs
labels.description: Improvements or additions to the documentation

labels.name: component: text field
labels.description: This is the name of the generic UI component, not the React module!

issue.body:
Early follow up to https://github.com/mui/material-ui/issues/19154#issuecomment-1741374856

Not the most exciting docs update, but I think we should explicitly discourage using `type="number"` on a TextField, remove the inputProps.pattern workaround, and steer attention towards Base's Number Input instead 😬 

Closes https://github.com/mui/material-ui/issues/29469
Closes https://github.com/mui/material-ui/issues/31114
Closes https://github.com/mui/material-ui/issues/36264
Closes https://github.com/mui/material-ui/issues/39370
Closes https://github.com/mui/material-ui/issues/39627

- [x] I have followed (at least) the [PR section of the contributing guide](https://github.com/mui/material-ui/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#sending-a-pull-request).

issue.title: [Menu] right click trigger context menu works unexpected

labels.name: bug 🐛
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: docs
labels.description: Improvements or additions to the documentation

issue.body:
<!-- Provide a general summary of the issue in the Title above -->

<!--
  Thank you very much for contributing to Material-UI by creating an issue! ❤️
  To avoid duplicate issues we ask you to check off the following list.
-->

## Current Behavior 😯
rigth click in the  text container, the context menu opend. then right click outside of the text container, the context menu still opend followed the mouse position 

<!-- Describe what happens instead of the expected behavior. -->

## Expected Behavior 🤔
when right click outside of the container , context menu should  be closed

<!-- Describe what should happen. -->

## Steps to Reproduce 🕹

<!--
  Provide a link to a live example (you can use codesandbox.io) and an unambiguous set of steps to reproduce this bug.
  Include code to reproduce, if relevant (which it most likely is).

  You should use the official codesandbox template as a starting point: https://material-ui.com/r/issue-template-next

  If you have an issue concerning TypeScript please start from this TypeScript playground: https://material-ui.com/r/ts-issue-template

  Issues without some form of live example have a longer response time.
-->

Steps:

2. right click the text container ,the context menu opened
3. keep context menu opend state, right click outside of the text container 
4. the context menu still opend follow with the mouse

## Context 🔦

<!--

-->

issue.title: [base-ui] Remove workarounds for unsupported browsers

labels.name: ready to take
labels.description: Help wanted. Guidance available. There is a high chance the change will be accepted.

labels.name: package: base-ui
labels.description: Specific to @mui/base

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: This is not a bug, nor a new feature.

issue.body:
Some Base UI components use workarounds for issues found in older browsers (IE, Safari < 13). We can remove them to reduce the bundle size:

- [ ] touch action support detection in useSlider: https://github.com/mui/material-ui/blob/846bc16fb3f02e9b64573a4aaaa0bd5aea2be36f/packages/mui-base/src/useSlider/useSlider.ts#L174-L194
- [ ] non-standard key codes in useSnackbar (`Esc`): https://github.com/mui/material-ui/blob/846bc16fb3f02e9b64573a4aaaa0bd5aea2be36f/packages/mui-base/src/useSnackbar/useSnackbar.ts#L43-L44
- [ ] IE-specific support in FocusTrap: https://github.com/mui/material-ui/blob/846bc16fb3f02e9b64573a4aaaa0bd5aea2be36f/packages/mui-base/src/FocusTrap/FocusTrap.tsx#L198-L205
- [ ] Handling focus on disabled elements in useInput: https://github.com/mui/material-ui/blob/846bc16fb3f02e9b64573a4aaaa0bd5aea2be36f/packages/mui-base/src/useInput/useInput.ts#L109-L114

Note that Material UI components that use these Base UI building blocks should still support these older browsers (until the next major version).

Part of #34510

comment.body: Go ahead, @ekailly!

issue.title: [docs][base-ui] POC for simpler Tailwind demos

labels.name: component: switch
labels.description: This is the name of the generic UI component, not the React module!

labels.name: package: base-ui
labels.description: Specific to @mui/base

labels.name: proof of concept
labels.description: Studying and/or experimenting with a to be validated approach.

issue.body:
This PR experiments with having simpler Base UI's demos when it comes to using Tailwind CSS. There are two aspects of the changes we could make:

- Treat the demo components as simplest as possible - we don't need to account for slots, slotProps and other props to be handled in the demo components, we can consider that the component has a simple API surface withprops that make sense in a design system like component.
- Use the tailwind plugin similar to the headless one. For this to work we need to have the state classes applied on all slots (see the Swtich.tsx's changes)

Other thoughts:
- the plugin works currently only with the global state classes, we will need to update it so that it works with class name specific classes 
- on the plugin support, we can go a step further and allow people to use selectors like `ui-switch-track` and add the classes related to the track slot on the class name prop itself. This will simplify the usage of the component, but will create bigger specificity for the slots
- on another thought, so that we don't have to decide on simple demo vs fully featured, we can have both of them, for e.g. on each demo we can link a fully featured component code, that people can copy and paste in their projects - it comes to deciding whether we want to make the demos simple, so that people are not taken off when they see how much code is required, or whether we want to make the fully feature component available immediatelly


Preview demo: https://deploy-preview-39502--material-ui.netlify.app/base-ui/react-switch/

TODO:
- [ ] Fix the sandbox

issue.title: [docs][base-ui] POC for simpler Tailwind demos

labels.name: component: switch
labels.description: This is the name of the generic UI component, not the React module!

labels.name: package: base-ui
labels.description: Specific to @mui/base

labels.name: proof of concept
labels.description: Studying and/or experimenting with a to be validated approach.

issue.body:
This PR experiments with having simpler Base UI's demos when it comes to using Tailwind CSS. There are two aspects of the changes we could make:

- Treat the demo components as simplest as possible - we don't need to account for slots, slotProps and other props to be handled in the demo components, we can consider that the component has a simple API surface withprops that make sense in a design system like component.
- Use the tailwind plugin similar to the headless one. For this to work we need to have the state classes applied on all slots (see the Swtich.tsx's changes)

Other thoughts:
- the plugin works currently only with the global state classes, we will need to update it so that it works with class name specific classes 
- on the plugin support, we can go a step further and allow people to use selectors like `ui-switch-track` and add the classes related to the track slot on the class name prop itself. This will simplify the usage of the component, but will create bigger specificity for the slots
- on another thought, so that we don't have to decide on simple demo vs fully featured, we can have both of them, for e.g. on each demo we can link a fully featured component code, that people can copy and paste in their projects - it comes to deciding whether we want to make the demos simple, so that people are not taken off when they see how much code is required, or whether we want to make the fully feature component available immediatelly


Preview demo: https://deploy-preview-39502--material-ui.netlify.app/base-ui/react-switch/

TODO:
- [ ] Fix the sandbox

comment.body:
> If we want to serve Tailwind users, maybe a more appropriate way is to have 1-1 mapping for the DOM. I don't say that we have to restructure the component, the Switch will be the default export just provide more lower-level elements

How do you envision it? Would components like `SwitchTrack` be used alongside the current slots implementation? It should be possible to implement it so that

```tsx
<Switch>
  <SwitchTrack className={({ disabled }) => disabled ? 'opacity-50' : '' } />
</Switch>
```

would be an alternative way of writing

```tsx
<Switch slotProps={{ track: ({ disabled }) => disabled ? 'opacity-50' : '' }} />
```

The downside of this is the introduction of yet another customization method. Plus, there will be a small perf impact and issue with SSR as the slot props wouldn't be known on the first render (but we potentially could get around that using `React.children`).

Anyway, while I think the DX of Tailwind is much better when the classes are applied to elements, I agree with [Diego's comment](https://github.com/mui/material-ui/pull/39502#issuecomment-1775134238) that we should wait for real-world feedback before introducing more significant architectural changes.

---

As for this PR, it's an improvement for sure. We're still a long way from a perfect Tailwind + Base UI integration, but it does make the demos more readable.
